author: Odeinoichus
title: Phone Home and Destroy Lord Vortech
review:
Set #71258 E.T. The Extra Terrestrial Fun Pack: Steven Spielberg’s iconic alien joins the host of other IPs in LEGO Dimensions and this family-friendly IP is a great addition to the game, but don’t just take my word for it, or something.

Packaging

Great looking package, LEGO E.T. is front and center on the front and the big scene is shown where Elliot and him fly on the bike. The back showcases the Adventure World in the bottom corner and it looks a little bland, but don’t let the image fool you, it’s an awesome looking world. But that’s for later.

Parts

Not a lot to discuss about this set, there’s some nice elements in it, but the rarest element seems to be the new printed 2x4 tile with a phone number pad on it.

Minifigures

E.T.: This character is rather simplistic in design, but that’s because LEGO rarely prints the short legs element, the torso is double-sided with some nice detailing and the head is a great new sculpt for this great character with a load of detailing thanks to the print used for the face. He is holding a plant and his Toy Tag is printed with the iconic over the moon scene on the back. (Meaning behind where the character stands.)

The build

Phone Home: You get to build a telephone, it’s an awesome quick little build and looks great. Very easy to follow along with on the digital instruction menu.

Mobile Uplink: Re-building the set into a satellite phone is just awesome, this design and the build is highly impressive and really fun. I had no troubles when building it either.

Super-Charged Satellite: Here comes the final build and it’s a great build, all three of the builds in this set are highly impressive and satisfying. Definitely a great trio of builds.

The completed model

Phone Home & Alternate Models: All three of these models are great looking items, I’d recommend getting the parts from your collection or the secondary market to make all three of them, the Phone Home is a solid looking model representing a home telephone set, the secondary model is a satellite phone which takes the pieces and re-arranges them perfectly to make such an interesting looking model. The satellite model is also really clever in design and is a great source for making some extra satellites with other parts to populate your LEGO Space/City display.

The Digital Content

The Adventure World: E.T.’s world is expansive and a great looking little town surrounded by some forests and mountain ranges. The digital space takes full advantage of the scenes from the movie and lets you experience it all. Solve puzzles, help characters out with quests and explore the game world to its full extent.

Battle Arena: Visit the E.T. Quarantine Quandary in Multiplayer and challenge up to three of your friends to do whatever it is you want to do or can do in the Battle Arena section of the game.

Character & Vehicle Abilities: E.T. has a lot of nice abilities, he can solve Growth puzzles without needing to use the keystone, can Fix-It, Illuminate, Stealth, Mini Access, Magic and Heart Regen, which I believe is unique to him and the Portal 2 Cube build.

The Phone Home uses Sonar Smash and Phone Home, which… I honestly have no recollection as to what this power does. I think it was a cosmetic thing which summoned E.T.s ship. The Mobile Uplink gains the Special Attack ability. The Super-Charged Satellite can Destroy Silver and Gold LEGO Objects, interact with Flight Docks and Flight Cargo Hooks and Tow-Bar, it is the most vehicle based toy E.T. has.

Overall opinion

Recommended. I recommend picking this set up not only for the digital content, but because E.T. as a character is highly fun looking in design and the Minifigure can join your Star Wars alien collection thanks to ILM sticking them into the Senate Scenes in the Prequel Trilogy. Everything about this set is really fun and I’m highly impressed with it, no glitches at all to report on the digital side of things. Recommended.

author: Studded_Dud
title: E.T. Phone 5 Stars
review:
Building Experience: E.T. has a very good looking flower that he holds. The phone is a very cool build and it actually looks quite like an actual phone.

Parts: There are some pretty good parts including E.T.'s moulded head. It includes a whip which looks excellent as the cord for the phone. There is one printed tile that has the numbers for the phone. There is a silver radar dish on the bottom and of course the trans-yellow 2x2 round brick that all year two Dimensions sets include.

Playability: The physical build doesn't actually have any real play features, but in-game there is plenty for play. This unlocks many abilities from both the phone and E.T. himself. It also unlocks the E.T. world where you can free roam and complete quests around with all the characters that you own.

Value For Money: Though this set only has 42 parts and costs £14.99 / $11.99 it has very good value for the game as it is the only pack that can unlock the E.T. world which is quite necessary to beat the complete game.

Overall: Overall this is a really great set that deserves 5 stars and to be in your collection especially if you are a fan of the great movie. If you have not seen the movie it is a classic and a must watch.

author: Brick_Connections
title: Dimensions does it again!!!
review:
I've always loved Dimensions. I got into the game in 2016, shortly after this Fun Pack was released. When I bought the game, I knew I had to get this fun pack. This is one of my most favourite fun packs of the game and love the 80s nostalgia.

 

Packaging

As always, the Dimensions packaging style is different from normal LEGO sets, but has always been welcomed by me. The picture of the moon is one of the most iconic scenes in the film, and was awesome to see here.

 

Minifigure

There's only one minfigure in this fun pack, hence the name 'Fun Pack', but it is an awesome one. It's also exclusive!!! The printing on the front and back of the torso are fantastic and very true to the source material. The head mold is obviously new for the time and captures E.T.'s head shape perfectly. The addition of the flower is an obvious nod to the popular trop in the film where the flower wilts, but is later re-grown by E.T. The toy tag has some awesome printing as well, including the iconic 'bike across the moon' icon. 

 

Build

The other build in this pack, labelled Phone Home, is an obvious nod to E.T.'s famous catchphrase "E.T. phone home". The build resembles a common 80s household caller and receiver. The other builds, called Mobile Uplink and Super-Charged Satellite are awesome as well. The Mobile Uplink closely resembles the 'phone' E.T. builds in the film, while the Super-Charged Satellite resembles a satellite. All three builds and the E.T. minifigure have incredible abilities inside the core game.

 

Gameplay

Adventure World

In the core LEGO Dimensions videogame, the fun pack unlocks the E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial Adventure World. Inside this world is a bunch of nostalgic easter eggs to the film, as well as in-game characters seen. You can accept quests from Elliot, Michael, Gretie, Mary, and Keys and visit locations such as Elliot's house, E.T.'s spaceship, and the elementary school. 

Minifigure

When you play as E.T. in game, you get many abilities to choose from, some echoing moments in the film. He can do Fix-It spots, echoing his ability to fix things in the film; growth, echoing the flower growing; heart regeneration, echoing his healing abilities; magic, echoing his ability to move things with his mind; and stealth, echoing Gertie's costume for the alien as well as some others.

Gadget

The gadget has some callbacks as well. When a character uses 'Phone Home', it calls in Elliot on his BMX bicycle. You can then ride around on the bike as well as fly it, an obvious nod to the end of the film. Similarly, when a character uses 'Mobile Uplink', a brick-built miniature version of E.T.'s Spaceship appears. You can ride on this as well. The last rebuild, 'Super-Charged Satellite' is a flying vehicle that shoots a powerful laser beam out the front.

 

Overall

The set is price in retrospect when compared price-per-peice, but it's still a wonderfully designed set and worth the price, even if you don't have the core game. You can use the figure in the game or out in your own LEGO play or display.
